Acioly is an architect and urban planner, a development practitioner with more than 30 years of experience in planning, design, management, implementation and evaluation of housing and urban development policies and projects in over 25 different countries. 

He has lived or worked continuously in more than 10 countries, often occupying leading positions, working closely with decision makers, senior executives and policy makers of governments, scholars and academic institutions, civil society organizations and community-based organizations. 

His career spanned from theory and practice in a continuum from active professional engagements to academic works in post-graduation education and problem-solving courses linking urban planning, housing, urban regeneration and slum upgrading.
Acioly has worked on urban plans, housing projects, urban regeneration and slum upgrading projects. He also worked as programme manager and technical advisor on urban planning, housing reforms, institutional and policy development, urban management, action planning and city development strategies. 

Next to his practical experience, he also wrote, published and lectured extensively on several city and urban development topics building an extensive academic curriculum. He is the author of books and articles dealing for example with housing development, planning and designing slum upgrading, urban informality, urban densities, strategic planning and participatory urban management. He has been invited to and is frequent keynote speaker in many important world conferences and symposia organized by universities and national and international institutions. He has moderated and facilitated global meetings and inter-governmental policy dialogues.

profile_positions.description:
The EU Programme “International Urban Cooperation: Sustainable and Innovative Cities and Regions – Regional Action Latin America and the Caribbean” (IUC-LAC) is funded by the European Union's Partnership Instrument which supports the realization of EU policy objectives in areas including climate change and the external projection of the EU's growth strategy "Europe 2020". The Partnership instrument is managed by the European Commission Foreign Policy Instrument (FPI).
The programme contributes to improved international urban and regional policy diplomacy and increased decentralized cooperation on sustainable urban development, climate change through a focus on sustainable energy, and innovation for local and regional development.
IUC-LAC enhances city-2-city cooperation, implements the Global Covenant of Mayors, promotes peer-2-peer learning and the formulation of Action Plans on sustainable energy and climate change adaptation and mitigation, and the development of business opportunities and private sector engagement in urban projects. More than 350 cities have joined and signed up the covenant in Latin America and the Caribbean and many city pairings have been established. The SDGs and the NUA are important agenda’s in this program in addition to the EU vision for 2050.

profile_positions.description:
Acioly is currently head of training and capacity building of the United Nations Human Settlements Programme, UN-Habitat (from 2012 to date) where he leads a number of programmes and activities to strengthen the capacity of local and national government institutions, NGO's and training and knowledge based institutions in the broad field of housing and urban development.
He is a frequent keynote speaker in international seminars and symposia, a visiting scholar to international education programmes and is often a moderator of policy dialogues and in-house staff development and team building processes within a variety of organizations.
Acioly leads a team of UN-Habitat experts who are involved in capacity building and technical assistance in Asia, Africa and Latin America.  He is is the overall coordinator of the Habitat Partner Universities Initiative (Habitat UNI) comprised of 169 universities and 1400 individual scholars and researchers associated with universities, the Cities Alliance sponsored Capacity Building of Policy Makers in Africa on Housing the Poor which draws on the Quick Guides for Policy Makers on Housing and the Institution Building Project in Korea to strengthen the International Urban Training Center-IUTC.  Acioly also provides in-house training to UN-Habitat staff and partners, city governments and different target groups, including mayors, decision makers and policy makers.  He was also responsible for the undertaking of the training needs assessment of the Saudi Future Cities Programme (Saudi Arabia) involving 17 cities and local governments.  Acioly supervised more than 30 training events and the round tables of universities and researchers during the Sessions of the World Urban Forum in Napoli (2012) and Medellin (2014).
See: http://unhabitat.org/street-led-city-wide-slum-upgrading-claudio-acioly-un-habitat/
profile_positions.title: Head Capacity Building

profile_positions.description:
During the period 2008-2012, Acioly was chief Housing Policy of UN-Habitat and coordinator of the United Nations Housing Rights Programme and of the Advisory Group on Forced Evictions to the Executive Director of UN-Habitat (AGFE). During his tenure as chief Housing Policy of UN-Habitat, Acioly developed and published the housing profile methodology and led the development and implementation of housing profiles researches in Malawi, Ghana, Uganda, Zambia, Vietnam, Nepal, Mexico, El-Salvador, Cuba and Ecuador.   The housing profile is a consultative and analytical tool that helps governments to unveil the bottlenecks and shortcomings hindering the performance of the housing sector, and serves as a tool to undertake institutional and policy reforms and formulate evidence-based national housing strategies.  He managed multiple programmes and projects, supervising national, international and UN-Habitat teams of experts and contributed directly to the development and implementation of UN-Habitat’s corporate strategic plan. This work is published in more than a dozen publications issued by UN-Habitat.  He authored important strategy papers in Housing and Slum Upgrading which have been incorporated into UN-Habitat’s Strategic Plan for 2014-2019.  He was the co-author of the theme paper for Habitat III that led to the resolution of UN-Habitat’s Governing Council to propose the Third United Nations Conference on Housing and Sustainable Urban Development.  He is the lead author of the UN-Habitat Strategy Paper entitled ‘Streets as Tools for Urban Transformation: street-led citywide slum upgrading’ published in 2014.
See: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FWe5IUKXVTY

profile_positions.description:
Acioly worked as a senior housing and land policy expert for the Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies-IHS, The Netherlands.  He led all advisory services and academic and educational activities in the fields of housing and land. This includes MSc master program on Land and Housing as well as short-term training on housing, inner city revitalization, urban renewal, informal settlement regularization, action planning, urban planning and computer-aided design.  He was team leader in various institutional development, training and research projects in the Middle East, Central and Eastern Europe and Latin America, most notably in Albania, Brazil, Bulgaria, Cuba, Moldova and Egypt where he spent a number of months. 
He was resident deputy team leader and training advisor (1997-1999) and resident programme manager and team leader (2000-2004) leading the implementation of a capacity building and institutional development project financed by the Dutch government in cooperation with the Egyptian Ministry of Housing, Public Utilities and Urban Communities that reached more than 2,000 Egyptian professionals. He also led the housing reform programme in Moldova for the World Bank and provided technical assistance to the Government of Moldova to support its transition towards a market-based housing sector, a work he initiated with the United Nations Development Programme-UNDP.  In Bulgaria, he also led the housing reform programme through a development programme financed by the Netherlands Government and worked as technical advisor to municipal governments and non-governmental organisations in Santo Andre, Porto Alegre, Recife and Rio de Janeiro.  In Rio, during the period 1996-2000 he worked closely with the project managers of the citywide slum upgrading Favela-Bairro programme and the Rio-Cidade Urban Revitalisation Programme providing technical advice and on-the job training on project management, action planning, team building and project impact assessment.

Staff member of the Social Housing Agency (SHIS) of the Government of Brasilia. Architect and urban planner at the Executive Group for the Upgrading of the Favelas and Squatter Areas of Brasilia (GEPAFI-Grupo Executivo Para o Assentamento de Favelas e Invasões do Distrito Federal. Designed several upgrading plans, low income housing projects and the mapping of the informal areas of Brasilia. Project Manager and Team Leader of the Candangolândia Upgrading and Sites & Services Project, involving 19 different communities, 3,000 plots and core housing units, estimated 12,000 people. Coordinated and managed the entire project development and implementation, supervising a team comprised of engineers, social workers, sociologists, builders, inspectors, utility companies and building contractors. The flagship project of GEPAFI. Co-authored the first Housing Policy of the city.
